Today, the U.S. Department of Agriculture extended waivers through as late as December 31, 2020, dependent on available funding. The move allows schools to offer meals to all children at no charge this fall to minimize the challenges of meal service during a pandemic.
This means that your students will be able to have a free Breakfast and a Free lunch each day at no charge regardless if your family is Paid, Reduced or Free.
You do not have to send money for your student’s lunch account at this time. There will be no refunds given at this time to parents who have already paid, as we do not know for sure how long the funds for free meals will last.
If your family has not already filled out a free or reduced lunch form for this school year, we urge you to do this before the end of September just in case we go back to the charging of school meals.
If our schools go to Phase Blue the food service department will continue to offer nutritious meals in a drive thru format. These meals will also be free until December 31st , but only to student’s registered at one of our schools.

☀️ With the current state of COVID-19, we want to remind you to practice your 5210+ EVERY DAY!

☀️ In these moments, we are reminded of why we teach these 5 healthy habits to your children and we are grateful to be in over 100 schools every year.
-------------------------
🍎🍑🌽🥒🍇 Eating a rainbow of fruits and veggies boosts your immune system - frozen and canned count too! 🌈

🤯🤬😖 Get off the screens! New information is emerging every minute and it is overwhelming. Be sure to set screen time limits for yourself ⬅️⬅️⬅️ and your family.

💧 💦 💧 💦 Drink water to stay hydrated!

😴 😴💤 💤 SLEEP! With extended spring breaks and time at home, take advantage of this time to rest, relax and connect with your family.
-------------------------

☀️ Follow UCHealth on Facebook to follow best practices and stay in touch with the local happenings.

☀️ Take time to be together and stay healthy!

Colorado Action for Healthy Kids
February 26 at 1:41 PM ·

Wellness Kit Wednesday
Columbine Elementary, Fort Morgan
The indoor recess season was off to a slow start in many parts of Colorado this year, but the cold and wet weather has finally arrived. In preparation, parents and staff at Columbine Elementary created four indoor recess wagons using the Classroom Physical Activity kit.

In previous years, students played board games or sat on a computer when the weather was bad. Now, they wheel the wagons around the school and use the fitness dice, yoga cards, activity spots, and juggling scarves to create their own self-guided movements. When the equipment is not in use for indoor recess, students have the option to check out a wagon to have an active birthday celebration. Find more active indoor recess ideas in Game On: https://www.actionforhealthykids.org/activity/active-indoor-recess/

I do understand that some roadways in Morgan County remain impassable due to blowing snow. I have spoken with Tim Musser and he has informed me that the county plans to begin clearing roadways early this morning with the significant reduction in the wind. Our buses will make every effort to pick-up students, but an inaccessible roadway is beyond the District's control.

Despite all efforts, we are still going to have some students who may be unable to come to school. If that is the case, obviously, they will not be penalized and they will be able to make up all of their missed work.

I know that this is a very difficult situation and that the weather has been extremely challenging. I thank you for your understanding.

Sincerely,



Dr. James Hammack

Fort Morgan and Morgan County residents can expect to see a large emergency response in various locations around the city starting April 3, but residents can rest assured it is an emergency exercise drill.

The Morgan County School District is participating in this mass-casualty exercise along with numerous other local and state agencies including the Colorado National Guard. The exercise will start the morning of Tuesday, April 3, with the mock scenario of an F-3 tornado that swept through the middle of the city, destroying schools, homes, buildings, businesses and public facilities.

The exercise will allow all of the participating agencies to practice how they would respond in such a situation, and help them to be better prepared to react if a real tornado came through the area.

Fort Morgan High School received an automated phone call Tuesday afternoon that an “active shooter exercise” was going to take place. Since there was no exercise scheduled with the local Fort Morgan Police Department, high school administration decided to be cautious and place the school on ‘lock out.’

A short time later, the high school received another automated phone call stating the ‘exercise’ was over. This phone call came from Langley Air Force Base in Langley, VA. This was a mis-directed automated phone call that came to the high school.

High school administration, along with District administration and the police department will continue to investigate how this happened and how we received this kind of a phone call. The staff and students at the high school, and all other schools in the district, were safe and secure at all times. Any safety procedures that were initiated were simply a precaution.

Please address any questions to the Office of the Superintendent. Thank you.
